Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Common rust of corn is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. It is one of the most frequently occurring foliar diseases of corn, capable of causing significant yield losses in susceptible hybrids when conditions are favorable for disease development.
causes: High humidity (>95%) or extended dew periods
symptoms: Small, circular to elongated cinnamon-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces
Pustules turn dark brown to black as they mature
Pustules can appear on stalks and husks in severe cases
Leaves may turn yellow and die in severe infections
Pustules rupture leaf surface, releasing powdery rust spores
Initial symptoms appear as flecks, then develop into pustules
Pustules are scattered across leaf surface rather than clustered
remedies: Apply appropriate fungicides at first sign of disease
Use systemic fungicides for better control
Time fungicide applications based on disease forecasts
Remove alternate host plants from field edges
Improve air circulation in the field
Monitor fields regularly during growing season
Consider fungicide application at tasseling stage if disease pressure is high
maintenance: Plant resistant hybrids when available
Avoid highly susceptible varieties in high-risk areas
Scout fields regularly, especially in humid conditions
Maintain balanced soil fertility
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization
Practice good field hygiene
Rotate crops with non-host plants
Time planting to avoid peak disease periods

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a devastating disease caused by the oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans. This is the same disease that caused the Irish Potato Famine and can destroy entire crops within days if conditions are favorable.
causes: Infected seed potatoes or tomato transplants
symptoms: Large, dark brown patches on leaves with pale green borders
White, fuzzy growth on leaf undersides in humid conditions
Dark brown lesions on stems and petioles
Firm, brown spots on fruit that may become mushy
Rapid wilting and death of foliage
Disease spreads quickly throughout the plant
Can kill plants within days under favorable conditions
remedies: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately - do not compost
Apply copper-based fungicides preventatively
Use fungicides containing chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper when disease is present
Avoid overhead watering and water early in the day
Increase plant spacing to improve air circulation
Remove volunteer tomato and potato plants
Clean and sanitize garden tools and stakes
maintenance: Plant resistant varieties when available
Ensure excellent soil drainage
Monitor weather conditions and disease forecasts
Practice crop rotation (3-4 years for tomatoes/potatoes)
Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Keep foliage dry and improve air circulation
Remove plant debris and weeds promptly
Avoid working with plants when wet

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani that affects tomatoes and potatoes. While not as rapidly destructive as late blight, it can significantly reduce yields and fruit quality.
causes: Infected plant debris from previous season
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target-like pattern)
Yellowing of leaves around the spots
Spots begin on older, lower leaves first
Leaf spots may merge and cause leaves to die
Stem lesions are dark, sunken and may have rings
Fruit can develop leathery, sunken spots near stem
Gradual defoliation from bottom up
remedies: Remove infected leaves immediately
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper
Rotate sprays between different fungicide types
Mulch soil to prevent spore splash
Prune lower leaves to improve air circulation
Support plants with stakes or cages
Maintain balanced nutrition with adequate calcium
maintenance: Plant resistant varieties when possible
Practice crop rotation (3-4 years minimum)
Space plants properly for good airflow
Water at the base of plants, avoid wetting leaves
Remove plant debris after harvest
Maintain soil fertility with regular testing
Apply preventive fungicides during humid weather
Monitor plants regularly for early symptoms

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold, caused by the fungus Passalora fulva (previously called Fulvia fulva), is particularly problematic in greenhouse tomatoes and outdoor tomatoes in humid climates.
symptoms: Pale green to yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces
Olive-green to brown velvety mold on leaf undersides
Leaves become yellow, then brown and wither
Infection typically starts on older leaves
Reduced photosynthesis and yield
Fruit rarely affected directly but may be smaller
Can cause significant defoliation in severe cases
remedies: Remove and destroy infected leaves
Apply approved fungicides at first sign of disease
Increase air circulation with fans
Reduce humidity through ventilation
Space plants properly
Avoid overhead irrigation
Prune to improve air flow
maintenance: Use resistant varieties in humid areas
Maintain greenhouse ventilation
Heat and vent to reduce humidity
Keep leaf surfaces dry
Remove crop debris after harvest
Sterilize greenhouse between crops
Monitor humidity levels
Regular inspection of plants
